facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 228 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 30th April 1970 of Delhi High Court in Criminal Revision No. 90 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated the 30th April, 1970 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Criminal

facts.text: Kamla Devi (Respondent No. 1) married to Bhagwan Dutt (appellant) on January 22, 1957 according to Hindu rites.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, Kamla Devi was married to the appellant Bhagwan Dutt on January 22, 1957 according to Hindu rites. out of this wedlock

facts.text: Daughter (Respondent No. 2) born to Kamla Devi and Bhagwan Dutt on November 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: out of this wedlock a daughter, Respondent No. 2, was born on November 22, 1957. On October 18, 1966, Respondent No. 1 filed a

facts.text: Kamla Devi filed petition for judicial separation against Bhagwan Dutt on October 18, 1966 on grounds of desertion and cruelty.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1966, Respondent No. 1 filed a petition against the appellant for judicial separation on the ground of desertion and cruelty.

facts.text: During pendency of judicial separation petition, Kamla Devi filed application under Section 488 CrPC for maintenance for herself and minor daughter.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that petition, she filed all application under s. 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, in the companyrt

facts.text: Application under Section 488 claimed maintenance on ground that Bhagwan Dutt neglected and refused to maintain wife and daughter.

anchor.surface_text: of the Magistrate, 1st Class, Delhi, claiming maintenance for herself and for her minor daughter, on the ground that the appellant had

facts.text: At date of Section 488 application, Kamla Devi employed as stenographer with monthly salary of Rs. 600/-

anchor.surface_text: neglected and refused to maintain them. At the date of the application Respondent No. 1 was employed as a stenographer on a monthly salary

facts.text: At date of Section 488 application, Bhagwan Dutt earning about Rs. 800/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: of Rs. 600/-. The appellant was at that time earning about Rs. 800/- per month. However, later on when the case was in the

facts.text: By time of revision in Sessions Court, monthly income of Kamla Devi and Bhagwan Dutt each increased by approximately Rs. 150/-

anchor.surface_text: Sessions Court in revision, the monthly income of each of them had increased by Rs. 1501-, approximately. By his order dated June 6,1969

facts.text: Magistrate, 1st Class, Delhi ordered on June 6, 1969 Bhagwan Dutt to pay Rs. 250/- per month maintenance: Rs. 175/- to wife, Rs. 75/- to child.

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate directed the husband to pay Rs. 250/- per month i.e. Rs. 175/- for the wife and Rs. 75/- for the child for their maintenance.

facts.text: Magistrate did not take into consideration Kamla Devi's own independent income while fixing her maintenance amount.

anchor.surface_text: While fixing the amount of maintenance for the wife, the Magistrate did number take into companysideration her own independent income.

facts.text: Bhagwan Dutt filed revision against Magistrate's order in Court of Session.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Magistrate, the husband went in revision to the Court of Session. The Additional Sessions Judge was of the view

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge held Kamla Devi's income substantial enough to maintain herself, so not entitled to maintenance; enhanced child's maintenance to Rs. 125/- pm during pendency and Rs. 150/- pm thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: that since the income of the wife was substantial and enough to maintain herself. she was number entitled to any maintenance. He was further

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge referred case to High Court under Section 438 CrPC recommending quashing of wife's maintenance and enhancing child's.

anchor.surface_text: of the opinion that Rs. 75/- p.m. allowed to the child being inadequate, it deserved to be raised to Rs. 125/- p.m. for the period of

facts.text: Delhi High Court single Judge held that under Section 488 CrPC, court need not consider wife's personal income; declined reference for quashing wife's maintenance but accepted enhancement for child.

anchor.surface_text: He referred the case to the High Court under s. 438 of the Code with a recommendation that the order of the Magistrate to the extent

facts.text: Bhagwan Dutt appealed High Court judgment to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the judgment of the High Court, the husband has number companye in appeal before us. The material part of Section 488

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment, remanded to trial Magistrate to refix maintenance considering wife's income and fresh evidence for daughter.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and send the case back to the trial Magistrate

issues.text: Can the income of the wife be taken into account in determining the amount of maintenance payable to her under Section 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 ?

anchor.surface_text: Can the income of the wife be taken into account in determining the amount of maintenance payable to her under Section 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 ?

issues.text: Does this recasting of the old provision signify any fundamental change in the law? Or, has this been done merely to clarify and make explicit what was formerly implicit ?

anchor.surface_text: A comparative study of the provisions set out above would show that while in Section 488 the condition unable to maintain itself apparently attached only to the child and not to the wife, in Section 125, this condition has been expressly made applicable to the case of wife. Does this recasting of the old provision signify any fundamental change in the law? Or, has this been done merely to clarify and make explicit what was formerly implicit ?

issues.text: whether there is any thing in s.488 which is inconsistent with s.23 or any other provisions of the act

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore resolves itself into the issue whether there is any thing in s.488 which is inconsistent withs .23 or any other provisions of the act. This matter is no longer res integra.

issues.text: Whether Section 488 confers an absolute right on a neglected wife to get an order of maintenance against the husband

anchor.surface_text: Section 488 does not confer an absolute right on a neglected wife to get an order of maintenance against the husband nor does it impose an absolute liability on the husband

arguments.claim: Object is to prevent vagrancy; maintenance for modest living consistent with family status, considering both incomes.

anchor.surface_text: The object of those provisions being to prevent vagrancy and destitution, the Magistrate has to find out as to what is required by the wife to maintain a standard of living which is neither luxurious number penurious, but is modestly consistent with the status of the family.

holdings.text: Keeping in view the object, scheme, setting and the language of these associate provisions in Chapter XXXVI, it seems to us clear that in determining the amount of maintenance under s. 488 1 , the Magistrate is companypetent to take into companysideration the separate income and means of the wife.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view the object, scheme, setting and the language of these associate provisions in Chapter XXXVI, it seems to us clear that in determining the amount of maintenance under s. 488 1 , the Magistrate is companypetent to take into companysideration the separate income and means of the wife.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary power indicated by 'may'; preventive purpose against vagrancy; s.489 contemplates wife's financial changes; distinction between petition maintainability and quantum fixation; standards of modest living considering both incomes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'may' precludes absolute right/obligation; discretion exercised judicially for social purpose of moral obligation enforcement without full matrimonial adjudication.

holdings.text: For the reasons aforesaid, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and send the case back to the trial Magistrate to refix the amounts of maintenance. In the case of the wife, he shall together with other relevant circumstances, take into account her income also. In the case of the daughter, he shall afford opportunity to the parties to lead fresh evidence and then refix her allowance.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and send the case back to the trial Magistrate to refix the amounts of maintenance. In the case of the wife, he shall together with other relevant circumstances, take into account her income also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holding to facts: Magistrate erred by not considering wife's income (f12); incomes changed (f10); fresh evidence for child; High Court erred on principle.
